Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Weighted Inequalities and their Applications to Quasiconformal Maps
Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of this proposal is the study of interactions between quasiconformal (QC) mappings, geometric analysis (in particular uniform rectifiability), Fourier analysis, and geometric combinatorics. Five problems will be addressed. The unifying method to be employed is an underlying geometric-combinatorial vision which often manifests itself through multiscale analysis (i.e., the analysis of a problem on different scales.) This method will be applied in the contexts of so called "K-QC mappings" (mappings sending an infinitesimal circle/ball to an infinitesimal ellipse/ellipsoid), geometric measure theory (GMT, which analyzes sets and measures on them -these are generalizations of length, area and volume-), harmonic analysis (decomposing a signal into elementary pieces of wavelike character), and potential theory (study of Coulombic potential and related topics.)

The mathematical objects involved have found abundant applications in other disciplines, so the problems proposed will advance knowledge in those areas. Fractals (GMT) appear naturally in electrodeposition and Diffusion Limited Aggregation. The internal structure of lungs has a high fractal dimension (to capture more oxygen.) Fourier analysis is often applied in signal and image processing. QC maps are solutions to problems in non-linear elasticity, and have found applications in string theory. Uniform rectifiability appears in minimizers of the Mumford-Shah functional (originally used for image segmentation.) Geometric combinatorics is used for fair division and voting problems in the social sciences, and for phylogenetic trees models in biology. Distance sets are used in industry to study the dimensionality of data sets. The PI will continue preparing students for the Putnam Competition, participating in the Math Club, and mentoring graduate students informally in the context of graduate courses. Fractals and geometric combinatorics are excellent areas for promoting teaching and training of undergraduates and postdocs. The basic notions of multiscale analysis, dimension, combinatorics, etc. are deep enough to convey some flavor of research yet can be successfully explained in an elementary way.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Regarding intellectual merit: in operator theory, one seeks to understand operators in terms of simple and nice ones, e.g. so-called unitary or normal operators. It is a question of fundamental importance to know when a small or simple perturbation of these nice operators is still one of these nice operators. This question is equivalent to a harmonic analysis question, which has been a guiding theme in the project funded, namely two weight inequalities for singular integral operators (SIOs). Inspired by the operator theory intuition, Nazarov-Treil-Volberg formulated a conjecture regarding the two weight inequality for the simplest, non-trivial SIO (the Hilbert transform): that the two weight inequality is equivalent to 3 conditions (a so-called Muckenhoupt type condition and two testing conditions). (Strictly speaking there is a family of somewhat related theorems and conditions that suggest further conditions that could be relevant.)

This question was finally solved, after 4-5 years of effort, for the Hilbert transform, by the PI and collaborators in a two-part paper (the PI is a coauthor in the first part). In that solution, there is a small technical condition that was later removed by Hytonen, a Finnish mathematician. Moreover, along the way, Hytonen also solved a related problem (which was also a proposed problem for this proposal), namely the A2 conjecture, for which he was awarded a lecture at the International Congress of Mathematicians and the European equivalent of the NSF CAREER grant (further highlighting the importance of this circle of questions).

After the aforementioned question was settled for the Hilbert transform, the case of other SIOs becomes hopefully more tractable, and that is what the PI and collaborators (Eric Sawyer from Canada and Chun-Yen Shen from Taiwan) have been attacking. After several years of efforts, important progress has been made, but the problem is still unsolved. Indeed, in the case of the Hilbert transform, certain conditions (energy conditions) are a consequence of the 3 aforementioned conditions. Furthermore, all known proofs of the two weight inequality need these energy conditions as auxiliary hypotheses. However, in a recent paper, the PI and collaborators (Sawyer and Shen) have proved that the energy conditions are not necessary in general.

The quest for the proof of this fundamental conjecture continues, and the PI is the only US-based node of his team, which as of now holds the most recent advances in this problem.

Regarding broader impact, the PI has been actively involved in the education of the future scientific workforce of the US. Indeed, he has developed from scratch a problem-solving course aimed at undergraduate students. Problem-solving is a fundamental skill for researchers and for everyday life, and the course developed by the PI precisely addresses the development of ingenuity and rigor. The course is complemented by another unofficial course that prepares for the Putnam mathematical competition.

Furthermore, the PI has co-advised a Hispanic graduate student who is currently working for Google, and is currently advising two other students (one of them is an international student). The PI regularly gives presentations to high school students abroad and in Michigan to promote STEM recruitment. Indeed, in the PI's experience, talented domestic students often prefer an applied or lucrative career path, so recruitment of talented students for basic science research often has to be done abroad. The PI systematically uses his international collaborations and contacts to enhance this recruitment.

The PI further posts his papers in arXiv, a free internet server, and gives talks on his results, to further disseminate them.
